## Recall

Recall from last lecture we studied

* **Random** sampling: where we select the sample from the population in an unbiased fashion
* Bias: A sample is biased if some observational units have a higher **probability** of being
included in the sample. 

Keywords: **random** and **probability**




## Probability

* In short: probability is the study of randomness.
* The study of probability lies in one [historical constant](https://www.google.com/search?q=probability&newwindow=1&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjnvJG7_oTQAhVIQiYKHSQ7CnoQ_AUICSgC&biw=2559&bih=1316&dpr=2#newwindow=1&tbm=isch&q=history+of+gambling).

## Simulations via Computer

> * The mathematical approach to studying probability requires more mathematical background: set theory, discrete math, calculus, and later on measure theory.
> * The [simulation approach](http://rpruim.github.io/eCOTS2014/Workshop/ResamplingPres.html) does not, but requires a computer's **random number generator** to generate simulations. Why?

## Critical Note

The "random simulation" in question is not limited to coin flips.





## Analogy for Random Simulation

For **any** random simulation, think to this: POWERBALL

<img src="../figure/powerball.jpg" alt="Drawing" style="width: 600px;"/>





## Analogy for Random Simulation

<img src="../figure/powerball.jpg" alt="Drawing" style="width: 400px;"/>

Different simulations can be set by varying the settings:

> 1. How many balls do you have?
> 1. What are written on the balls?
> 1. Do the balls have equal probability of being picked?
> 1. How many balls do you pick?
> 1. What do you do with a ball after you've picked/recorded it?




## Analogy for Random Simulation

```{r}
library(mosaic)
rflip()
rflip(10)
simulations <- do(10) * rflip(10)

library(dplyr)
as_data_frame(simulations)

simulations %>% 
  group_by(heads) %>%
  summarize(count = n())



do(3)*rflip()
do(3)*resample(c(1:6))
do(3)*shuffle(c(1:6))
```
